content.question: ​A student starts to drive to school from home in a straight line and quickly realizes they forgot their backpack. The student stops the car and then drives back to their starting position at home. For this context, which of the following graphs could model the velocity <math alttext="v"><mi>v</mi></math>, in miles per hour, of the car as a function of time <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>, in hours? (Assume driving away from home involves positive velocity.)

choices.label:
​

The horizontal axis is labeled t. The vertical axis is labeled v of t. Neither axis has a scale or tick marks. Moving from left to right: 

The curve begins at the origin and gradually increases to a high point. 

The curve then decreases back to the horizontal axis.

The section of the curve from the origin to the high point and back to the horizontal axis appears to be symmetric about the vertical line through the high point. 

The curve continues to decrease to a low point below the horizontal axis. The high point and low point appear to be the same distance from the horizontal axis. 

The curve increases from the low point to the horizontal axis, where it ends. 

The section of the curve from the point at which it crosses the horizontal axis, reaches the low point, and returns to the horizontal axis appears to be symmetric about the vertical line through the low point. 

The point at which the curve crosses the horizontal axis appears to be halfway between the beginning point at the origin and the ending point on the far side of the horizontal axis.

​

The horizontal axis is labeled t. The vertical axis is labeled v of t. Neither axis has a scale or tick marks. Moving from left to right: 

The curve begins at the origin and gradually decreases to a low point. 

The curve then increases back to the horizontal axis. 

The section of the curve from the origin to the low point and back to the horizontal axis appears to be symmetric about the vertical line through the low point. 

The curve continues to increase to a high point above the horizontal axis. The low point and high point appear to be the same distance from the horizontal axis. 

The curve decreases from the high point to the horizontal axis, where it ends. 

The section of the curve from the point at which it crosses the horizontal axis, reaches the high point, and returns to the horizontal axis appears to be symmetric about the vertical line through the high point. 

The point at which the curve crosses the horizontal axis appears to be halfway between the beginning point at the origin and the ending point on the far side of the horizontal axis.

The curve appears to be symmetric about the vertical line through the high point.

The curve appears to be symmetric about the vertical line through the low point.
